title: In Move From 'Endless Wars,' Trump Stokes Mideast Uncertainty
summary: Green light to Turkey to attack Kurdish fighters in Syria is seen as a flashing yellow by others. Turkey's military offensive against U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in Syria opens an uncertain new chapter in Washington's Middle East policy as President Trump willingly cedes influence to Ankara and other regional players.

title: New York Sues Over Lake Ontario Flooding
summary: The state says a management plan has contributed to flooding that has caused about $1 billion in property damage. New York is suing an international body charged with regulating water flows on the Great Lakes, contending a recent management plan has contributed to flooding along Lake Ontario that has caused about $1 billion in property damage.

title: Back to You, Nancy
summary: Trump calls the Speaker's bluff on her impeachment tactics.. The White House letter late Tuesday telling Speaker Nancy Pelosi that President Trump won't cooperate with her impeachment inquiry is causing heartburn among all the usual suspects. Readers should ignore the fainting spells over "a constitutional crisis" and keep in mind that this is largely a political response to a political attack by House Democrats.

title: EU Looks to Tweak Method for Compiling Dirty-Money Blacklist
summary: New proposed methodology follows concerns about transparency in the previous process for designating high-risk countries. The European Union is working on a new approach for flagging countries with weak anti-money-laundering laws after the bloc's previous attempt to create a blacklist failed earlier this year.

title: Turkey Begins Offensive Against U.S. Ally in Syria
summary: Ankara begins operation to seize territory held by Kurdish forces; Trump threatens reprisals if Turks don't exercise restraint. The Turkish military began an offensive in Syria to seize territory held by U.S.-backed Kurdish forces, opening a new front in the war-ravaged country and drawing a renewed defense by President Trump of his decision to shift U.S. troops out of the area, effectively enabling the start of the assault.

title: The Kavanaugh Referrals
summary: The Senate identified four false accusers. Where's the inquiry?. No news, though, regarding the four false accusers whom the Senate referred for potential criminal inquiry. This week nine Republicans asked the Justice Department for an update.

title: No More Rule by Memorandum
summary: Trump gives federal agencies good guidance on bad 'guidance.'. President Trump has cut enough red tape in office to suffice for 100 golf course grand openings. An official tally isn't out for fiscal 2019, which ended Sept. 30, but the American Action Forum estimates another $8.5 billion in savings.

title: Report Traces Source of U.K. Fraud Office Case Delays
summary: A review by an independent U.K government inspector addressed the causes of delays in some cases before the Serious Fraud Office. The U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office at times has struggled to appropriately staff cases and process digital materials, an independent government inspector said.

title: Food Companies Add AI to Their Recipes
summary: Artificial intelligence can speed up the process of finding new flavors and products. Cumin pizza, anyone?. title: A War of Words Over Labeling for Plant-Based Meat and Milk
summary: Farmers and ranchers square off with others over names such as almond milk and veggie burger. As plant-based alternatives eat into the markets for traditional meat and milk, a war of words has erupted over how the new foods and beverages are labeled. Dairy farmers and cattle ranchers object to what they see as misnomers like almond milk and veggie burgers for products that contain no dairy or meat, and they want strict enforcement of labeling rules. Makers of the new foods are pushing back.

title: Ted McKinney on Agricultural Trade With China and Japan

title: 'Unbreakable' Review: Clearing Obstacles
summary: In 1937, a Czech aristocrat became the ﬁrst woman to win what was (and still is) considered the world's most dangerous steeplechase.. The whole point of a challenge is that it be achievable. Unsolvable puzzles and unwinnable games are of no interest to anyone. No one would watch a foot race in which the hurdles were set at 7 feet. What would be the point? The 19th-century designers of the race called the Velká Pardubická came close to designing an impossible steeplechase, journalist Richard Askwith concludes in a book that is as much a story of the race itself as it is a biography of the only woman ever to have won it. It took years, he recounts, "to work out just how far back the frontiers of common sense could be pushed in pursuit of the ultimate test of horsemanship. The answer was: quite far."

title: Insult, Injury and Religious Liberty
summary: A Catholic charity wins a modest victory, but only because of a state official's ugly rhetoric.. Some conservatives are hailing a victory for religious liberty in Michigan, but there's less to it than meets the eye. On Sept. 26 a federal district court ordered the state to continue allowing St. Vincent Catholic Charities to participate in its foster-care programs. Judge Robert Jonker's ruling makes clear that the Supreme Court's decision in Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission (2018) gives life to some lawsuits over hostile treatment of religious believers. But it also shows the limits of the majority opinion in Masterpiece Cakeshop, which doesn't do much to secure the substantive rights of religious objectors.

summary: Richard Nixon's inquisitors knew that a strictly partisan inquiry would fail.. The House Democratic impeachment inquiry is unserious. The estimated length of shelving installed in the new structure's six storage rooms, each tailored to different styles of art and conservation requirements.

title: Inside an 18th-Century Manor Home in Brittany, France
summary: French design dealer François Laffanour applied his renegade spirit to reviving an 18th-century manor house in Brittany. At Design Miami, or any of the other international fairs where François Laffanour exhibits, the French furniture dealer is a recessive figure, his wiry frame and dollop of silver hair sequestered at the back of his booth behind a table by Charlotte Perriand or a Jean Prouvé desk. But on the golf course, he's all action. Playing the front nine before lunch at his home club in Brittany, Laffanour, 66, covers the distance between holes like a jackrabbit, wheeling his cart through a pine-scented landscape that slopes down toward the pink granite coastline and turquoise sea for which this part of France is known. When he hoists his clubs into the back of his Jaguar XJ Executive, he nudges the trunk closed in a gesture reminiscent of John Cassavetes, the late American actor and director whom he somewhat resembles and admires for his aura of cool.

title: American Delays 737 MAX's Return, Grounding Costs Mount
summary: Carriers grapple with capacity crunch as Boeing prepares fixes to aircraft's systems. American Airlines Group Inc. said it expects Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX will remain out of service until January, the latest example of how the grounded plane continues to create additional costs and logistical burdens for carriers and passengers.

title: Love the TV Series? Here's the Podcast.
summary: After fans gobbled up 'Stranger Things' and 'Chernobyl' podcasts, networks and streaming services have begun producing companion audio programs to boost TV viewer loyalty. When Craig Mazin asked HBO to work with him on a podcast to accompany his five-part miniseries "Chernobyl," he didn't expect it to resonate beyond a subset of Soviet history buffs seeking more information about the 1986 nuclear explosion. In pitching the project, he told HBO's marketing department that his intention was to be as "anti-promotional as possible," adding that "if 12 people listen to it but they are the hard-core Chernobyl nerds and they love it, then that's a job well done."

title: The Rays Have a Shot at an All-Time Baseball Stunner
summary: Tampa Bay forced a Game 5 in the ALDS after winning their second straight game against the heavily favored Houston Astros. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.-There are very few real upsets in the Major League Baseball postseason. The history of randomness this time of year is too great-and the playoff teams too close in talent-to believe too strongly in what is or isn't possible in the course of a mere five or seven games. But there is a very real upset brewing in the American League.

title: Mexican Inflation Eases to Be in Line With Central Bank Target
summary: Outcome supports expectations for continued interest-rate cuts amid a sluggish economy. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's inflation eased in September, coming in line with the Bank of Mexico's 3% target for the first time in three years and supporting expectations that the central bank will keep lowering interest rates amid a sluggish economy.

title: No Deal: Why Buying the London Stock Exchange Is Hard to Do
summary: Hong Kong exchange's pulled offer for the LSE highlights the difficulties of cross-border deals between trading venues. London Stock Exchange Group PLC's dismissal of the Hong Kong exchange's almost $37 billion takeover attempt underscores the challenges global exchanges face trying to complete cross-border deals amid geopolitical upheaval.

title: 'God and Money': Graft in Peru Sparks Political Reckoning
summary: Resume Subscription. LIMA-When President Martín Vizcarra dissolved the opposition-controlled Congress last week, angry lawmakers called it a coup. Yet many Peruvians saw it as a righteous act, like closing a rowdy red-light district.

title: Big Tech's Antitrust Game Is Changing
summary: Chip maker Broadcom is a test case for the European Union's new approach to quickly stopping what it sees as anticompetitive behavior. Big tech used to be able to stall for time when dealing with European Union antitrust cases. The tactic may not work for much longer.

title: Social Media Can't Afford to Forget Mom and Dad
summary: Generation Z has significant influence over household expenses, but it may not be enough to dominate social-media spend. Children and teenagers don't earn much money themselves, but that has never stopped advertisers from targeting them, as they can influence their household's spending in a major way.

title: PG&E Starts to Cut Power for Nearly 800,000 Customers
summary: Outages, which began in phases at midnight, are part of what is believed to be the largest such pre-emptive blackout to date.. PG&E Corp. has begun to shut off power to hundreds of thousands of people in California as it seeks to prevent its electric lines from sparking more deadly wildfires, in what is believed to be the largest such pre-emptive blackout ever.

title: Europe's Old Universities Spin Out New Tech Companies
summary: Resume Subscription. OXFORD, England-The world's oldest universities are learning to promote their newest technologies using American-style entrepreneurialism.

title: Fed Minutes to Shed Light on Internal Debate Over Rates
summary: They also will show officials' view of last month's money-market volatility and could highlight preferred solutions. The Federal Reserve will provide new clues about its thinking on where to set interest rates when it releases the minutes of its Sept. 17-18 meeting on Wednesday at 2 p.m. EDT.

title: New Cocoa-Pricing Method Makes for a Hot Commodity
summary: Rally is driven by uncertainty over a plan designed to aid farmers in Ghana and Ivory Coast. Cocoa prices are surging as traders grapple with a new method for pricing exports designed to alleviate poverty among farmers in Ivory Coast and Ghana, the world's largest growers of the chocolate ingredient.

title: General Strike Paralyzes Ecuador as President Stands by Austerity
summary: President Lenin Moreno returns to Quito in surprise move after temporarily relocating government away from capital. GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador-A general strike paralyzed much of Ecuador on Wednesday as week-old protests against President Lenín Moreno's decision to eliminate fuel subsidies continued and the government scrambled to restore order.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: James River Group to Cancel Auto Insurance for Uber Affiliate Rasier
summary: James River CEO says account hasn't met profitability expectations. James River Group Holdings Ltd. said Tuesday it delivered a notice of early cancellation of all insurance policies issued to Rasier LLC, its largest customer.

title: New York to Crack Down on Illegal Selling of Statue of Liberty Boat Tours
summary: City to target sellers who illegally hawk tickets for tours that sail around Liberty Island but don't stop. New York City is stepping up its enforcement of the illegal sale of Statue of Liberty boat tours a day after actor Alec Baldwin said he was duped into buying fake tickets for his family.

title: Justices Spar Over Gay Employee Cases
summary: Arguments weigh whether 1964 Civil Rights Act forbids discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court spent two tense hours on Tuesday weighing whether the nation's bedrock civil-rights law forbids employers from discriminating against gay or transgender employees.

title: Expanded U.S. Trade Blacklist Hits Beijing's AI Ambitions
summary: Move threatens Chinese companies' access to crucial components, relationships with U.S. firms. The U.S. decision to add eight Chinese companies to its trade blacklist strikes directly at China's ambitions in artificial intelligence, threatening its companies' access to crucial components and relationships with U.S. firms.

title: Ecuador's President Relocates Government Amid Protests
summary: Flanked by military, Moreno vows not to reverse decision to scrap fuel subsidy. Demonstrators protesting the end of a fuel subsidy stormed Ecuador's Congress on Tuesday before police expelled them with tear gas, a day after President Lenin Moreno moved the administrative center of his government out of Quito.

title: Memo Shows White House Official's Alarm at Trump-Zelensky Call
summary: The presidents' conversation is at the heart of a Democratic-led impeachment inquiry into whether Mr. Trump abused his office. President Trump's July 25 phone call with his Ukrainian counterpart had so alarmed a White House official that he called a colleague at the CIA the next day to share his concerns, according to a memorandum.

title: Lions Gate Considers Spinning Off Starz Through Investment Vehicle
summary: Move would help struggling studio unload a significant portion of its debt. Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. is considering splitting off its Starz premium-cable channel into a separate company, as the studio looks to reduce its hefty debt load and allow shareholders to invest directly in either of the businesses, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: GM-UAW Contract Talks Zero In on Wages
summary: Pay increases are among the few remaining issues as the sides strive for deal to end 23-day strike. General Motors Co. and the United Auto Workers are down to a crucial topic at the bargaining table: wages.

title: White House Refuses to Cooperate With Impeachment Probe
summary: Trump administration keeps ambassador from testifying about his role in Ukraine controversy. WASHINGTON-The White House said it won't cooperate with the House impeachment probe and the administration blocked the deposition of a U.S. ambassador seen as central to the Ukraine controversy, marking clear battle lines in the fight between President Trump and Democratic lawmakers.

title: New York City's First Vaping-Related Death Is a Bronx Teen
summary: The 17-year-old male was hospitalized in September and died Oct. 4. A Bronx 17-year-old is New York state's first vaping-related death, according to Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

title: Popchips Finds a New Owner in VMG-Backed Velocity Snack Brands
summary: Newly launched Velocity Snack Brands has acquired Popchips as its anchor brand.
